newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turk court to consider privatisation law objection.
newsitem.headline: Turk court to consider privatisation law objection.

text.p: Turkey's constitutional court is this week to consider a request for the annulment of two articles in the country's privatisation law, state-run Anatolian news agency reported on Tuesday.
The petitition, to be discussed on Wednesday, seeks the cancellation of articles relating to the evaluation of companies slated for privatisation and to the format of sell-off tenders.
The annulment request, which also relates to the creation of evaluation commissions, was made by deputies from two leftist parties who seek alternative procedures.
A fresh draft amendment to the privatisation law has already been presented by the government to parliament for its approval.
On Monday evening, the parliamentary planning and budget commission approved the draft changes redefining the formation and work of evaluation commissions and sell-off tender procedures in detail.
The draft also changes the selection of members on the High Board of Privatisation to include the deputy Prime Minister.

Turkey's Islamist-led government has targeted the acceleration of the country's long-standing privatisation programme as a key element of plans to raise revenues. The constitutional court earlier this year rejected a bid to block the sell-off of Turk Telekom, the centrepiece of the privatisation programme.
